newsitem.title: CHINA: Hong Kong ill-prepared for millenium bug - report.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong ill-prepared for millenium bug - report.

text.p: Hong Kong, one of the most computer-literate places in the world, is ill-prepared for the millennium bug that could bring computers crashing down in 2000, and must spend over US$170 million on the problem, a government survey said.
The police, for example, will have to spend more than $4 million by January 1, 2000, to protect their computer systems, according to a survey by the Hong Kong Productivity Council.
The survey, covering 1,000 companies and government departments, was the first major study on the millennium bug in Hong Kong.
It showed that 86 percent relied heavily on computers but nearly 40 percent of Hong Kong businesses were unaware of the problem. Small and medium-sized firms were most ill-prepared.
The so-called millennium bug refers to the inability of older computer programmes to process the last two digits of years correctly after December 31, 1999.
When 2000 arrives, the computers would misinterpret the "00" date as 1900 and crash or lose data, the theory goes.
A recent international study found the global spending on solving the problem would reach US$280 billion between 1997 and 2002, with US$145 billion of this to be spent in North America.
